coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
A measure of the acceptability or perceived fairness of an assessment. A legitimate assessment is one that has been conducted in a manner that allows users to be satisfied that their interests have been taken into account appropriately and that the process has been fair.
Source: Marine AoA
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Legitimacy

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: DG SANCO

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition: Eionet’s infrastructure for supporting and improving data and information flows. Reportnet is based on a set of inter-related tools and processes which all build on the active use of the World Wide Web.
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Reportnet

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition: Directors' meeting for environmental statistics and accounts
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: DIMESA

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
Infrastructure for Spatial Information in Europe.  established by Directive 2007/2/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 March 2007. INSPIRE aims at making available relevant, harmonised and quality geographic information to support formulation, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies and activities which have a direct or indirect impact on the environment. 
Source: EC INSPIRE Geoportal http://www.inspire-geoportal.eu/index.cfm
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: INSPIRE

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
Assessments that focus on a theme or issue other than a single sector of human activity.
Source: Marine AoA
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Thematic assessments

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
An ecosystem is a dynamic complex of plant, animal, and micro-organism communities and the non-living environment interacting as a functional unit.
Source: Millennium Ecosystem Assessment, 2005
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Ecosystem

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition: Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: OECD

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
It is concerned with whether the knowledge assembled in the assessment is believed to be valid. An assessment gains credibility and authority by virtue of its information, methods and procedures.
Source: Marine AoA
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Credibility

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
It denotes the ability of an assessment to address the particular concerns of those using it. It is also referred to as ‘salience’. An assessment is relevant if the user is aware of it and it informs his/her decisions or behaviour.
Source: Marine AoA
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Relevance

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
They identify and characterize the impacts of human activities and/or natural pressures on ecosystems and society
Source: Marine AoA
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Impact assessments

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition: pollution monitoring and assessment programme - Mediterranean  region
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: MED POL

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
It includes both the expert reports/summaries/scenarios and underlying data and information used in the analyses. 
Source: Marine AoA

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Stern report

Assessments that address a particular sector of human activity.
Source: Marine AoA
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Sectoral assessments

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition: European environment information and observation network
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: EIONET

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
Assessments that integrate across environmental, economic and social aspects, across industry sectors, and across ecosystem components (which may include land-based sources of inputs as well as land-based industries that depend on marine resources).
Source: Marine AoA

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition:
Assessments that typically describe the present and changing status of ecosystems.
Source: Marine AoA

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: ESPON2013

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition: Helsinki Commission - Baltic Marine  Environment Protection Commission
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: HELCOM

coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.definition: Formal efforts to assemble selected knowledge with a view toward making it publicly available in a form intended to be useful for decision-making (Mitchell and others 2006). By ‘formal’ the definition requires that the assessment should be sufficiently organised to identify components such as products, participants and issuing authority. ‘Selected knowledge’ indicates that the content has a defined scope or purpose and that not all information compiled and contributed is necessarily included in the report. The sources of knowledge may vary. While results from research and scientific knowledge predominate, assessments can supplement this with local, traditional or indigenous knowledge. Further, assessments can evaluate both existing information and research conducted expressly for the purpose. The definition also notes the importance of ensuring that assessments are in the public domain, as they may influence public debate and different types of decision-makers.
coordination.h2020.net_database_acronyms.name: Assessments

Institutional arrangements established to govern, guide and conduct the assessment and to ensure that the mandate and procedures are followed.
Source: Marine AoA
